addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

12 Novemb
r
1589 From M
r
Bodley
e recompense of
e Dutch Captains rec
o
m
e
ded in his former, to be furthered.
Barnevelts
opinion thereof, and
e Captaines nature to be considered.
e fort by
Rees
taken.
e Mutinie in
Sgraveswert
continueth. their demand is now 10000.
forces readie to marche into
France
to
e
K.
e Spaniards mutined in
Dermount.
Present consultations in state

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. at
e earnest sute of
some speciall persons heere, I writte unto yo
w
8
three
daies past, in
e favo
r
of a Dutche Captain,
who was also
e bearer of my letter, requesting
yo
r
H. that if for suche services, as he pretended
to have done to her Ma
tie
any order hath bin given
for his recompence, he may by yo
r
favorable
meanes be assisted to receave it. The same
party hath also solicited Barnevelt,
e Admi-
rall of Holland, and others, to recommend his
request to
Ortells
furtherance: whiche they
have done very earnestly. W
t
all they have
signified in secret to
e Captain, both by worde
and by writing, as he himself hath promised
me to declare unto yo
w
, and I have adverti-
sed in my former letter, That if her
Ma
tie
hath
passed any graunt of recompence unto him, it
is detened from him, and receaved by some
other, and that his request will be rejected,
and turned over to
e
states of
Ho
llande
, w
t
-
out
e privitie of her Ma
tie
. This is the mali-
cious conceat of
at man and those of his faction,
whiche I have alwaies bene persuaded, not w
t
-
standing all
e good meanes,
at can be used,
will never alter, untill her Ma
tie
shall ether
yelde to folowe his humo
r
in all thinges, or
seeke some meanes to cutte him of from
e govern-
ment. It may please yo
r
H. to observe w
t
all
e disposition of that Captaine, who is contended
to betray his frindes, at
e very same instant
fol.181v
as they doe their uttermost endevo
r
to stand
him in steed. For mine owne part, but that
in generall termes his service hath bin commen-
ded unto me, I have no other notice of his q
a
lities,
but I see by this dealing, he may be made to
serve to as many good purposes, as any other badde
instrument. The sconce by Rees,
w
ch
I signified in my last was besieged by
e
Enemie, is sithens taken, w
t
all
e Artillerie,
and other provision
at was in it: but
e souldiers
permitted to depart: who nether fought, nor at-
tended any shotte. The mutinie
in Sgravesweert will not be appeaced with
2500
li
sterling, whiche hath bin offered unto
them. Their demaund doth increase every
day, and doth not amount to so litle as 10000
li
which is not heere to be had. These five daies,
e Deputies
at came last out of England, have
continued
e report to
e
Generall states
, of
their negotiation there: whiche when they have
finished, I will calle earnestly uppon them,
to perfourme their promise to yo
r
H. in
e cause
of
Vasseur:
wherof I have putt them already
in remembraunce, and they have promised to
doe their best. Letters written
hither from
Collen
advertise, that there are in
a readines to marche towardes
e aide of the
Frenche king 7000 horse, and 50 Ensiegnes
of footmen, whose Rendevous is assigned
e 21
of this moneth at
Oppenhem
by
Ments.
It is held for certaine that
e Spaniardes, to the
nomber of 1500 ar mutined in Dermount, and
fol.182r
committ many outrages over all those quarters.
It is in deliberation among us at this
pnt
,
whether considering
e daunger of
Gelderland,
by
e meanes of
e Enemies returne, it be expedient
that all
e forces of these contreis both Inglishe
and others be sent thither. Wherupp
o
there is
nothing yet resolved. There is also a pre-
sent consultation about
e surprising of
e Ene-
mies fort before
Zutphen,
whiche is thought will
prove an easie enterprise, and very profitable
to
e contrey. The state heere is
very muche troubled by meanes of a newe mutinie
raised in their garrison of
Wijke,
a place of strength
and of great importance, about 2 leagues from
Utrecht,
where
e souldiers require to be discharged of their
obedience, and demaunde their full count and reckning.
In effect all their goverment heere is so voide of
that apperteneth to good government, so c
o
fuse, so
partiall, so full o f injustice, as almost all men
waxe weery of doing service to
e contrey. For
there is no governour to take notice of any mans
vertue or vices, wher
[.]
e good may stand inhope of reward, or e b
ad
de putte in feare of pu-
nishment. In w
ch
respect, and for
e harde measure
w
ch
they daily offer to their martiall men, it is greatly
feared,
at as
e have lately begonne in Sgraveswert
Liefkens Hoecke
,
Lillo,
and Wijke, so there wilbe, er
be long, a generall revolt in most of their gar-
risons.
This gentleman
M
r
Heidon
hath had occasions
to spend aswell as others in her Ma
ties
service,
and if the cariage of this letter may be worthe
fol.182v
any thing unto him of her Ma
ties
mony, yo
r
hono-
rable favo
r
wilbe very dutifully acknowledged.
And so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. N
o
12. 89
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
